explanation: BaSO4 is the mineral barite, which crystallizes in an orthorhombic Pnma structure (Z = 4). Reported experimental lattice constants are about a = 8.884 Å, b = 5.457 Å, c = 7.154 Å (giving a unit-cell volume ≈ 3.468×10^2 Å^3). BaSO4 is a wide-gap insulator; optical measurements and literature reports place the fundamental/optical gap in the deep-UV around ~5–5.5 eV (standard DFT-GGA values are typically lower, so an experimental-based estimate near 5.3 eV is given). The formation energy is estimated from the standard formation enthalpy of BaSO4 (on the order of −1.4 to −1.5×10^3 kJ·mol−1) → ≈ −15.2 eV per formula unit; dividing by 6 atoms per formula unit gives ≈ −2.5 eV/atom. Values given are approximate and based on experimental thermochemistry and crystallographic data; DFT-calculated values can differ depending on functional and reference energies.

Crystal structure: BaSO4 (barite) is the orthorhombic Pnma (often reported Pnma, Z = 4) sulfate mineral. Reported room-temperature lattice constants in the literature are about a = 8.88–8.89 Å, b = 5.45–5.46 Å, c = 7.15–7.16 Å (unit cell volume ≈ 346–348 Å^3). I adopt representative experimental values (a = 8.884 Å, b = 5.457 Å, c = 7.154 Å) giving a unit-cell volume ≈ 346.9 Å^3. Band gap: BaSO4 is a wide-gap insulator; optical/UV measurements and higher-level calculations typically place the gap in the ≈5–6 eV range. Density-functional (GGA/PBE) calculations typically underestimate gaps, so a reasonable prediction for the experimental optical gap is ≈5.5 eV. Formation energy: using standard formation enthalpy data for BaSO4 (~ -1.46 × 10^3 kJ/mol ≈ -15.18 eV per formula unit) and dividing by 6 atoms per formula unit gives ≈ -2.53 eV/atom. DFT formation energies can differ by a few tenths of an eV/atom depending on functional and reference states; the value given is an estimate based on experimental thermochemistry. Assumptions and uncertainties: lattice parameters are taken from typical room-temperature experimental reports for barite (Pnma); the band gap is an estimated optical gap (experimental values vary and DFT underestimates are common); formation energy is derived from experimental ΔfH° converted to eV/atom and should be treated as an approximate thermochemical value rather than a specific DFT-computed formation energy.

BaSO4 (barite) is a well-known orthorhombic (Pnma) sulfate. Reported experimental lattice parameters at ambient conditions are about a = 8.884 Å, b = 5.457 Å, c = 7.152 Å (unit cell volume ≈ 347 Å^3, Z = 4). The optical/UV band gap of BaSO4 is large — experimental optical absorption/reflectance values place it in the ~5–6 eV range; I give a mid-range estimate of ~5.5 eV (note: typical DFT-GGA values would underpredict this). The formation energy was estimated from tabulated standard formation enthalpy of BaSO4 (≈ -1.44 to -1.46 × 10^3 kJ/mol ≈ -15.0 eV per formula unit). Dividing by 6 atoms per formula unit gives ~-2.5 eV/atom. Values may vary with measurement/DFT method and temperature; the lattice parameters given are experimental ambient values.

BaSO4 (barite) is a well-known orthorhombic insulator (space group Pnma, Z = 4). Reported experimental lattice constants for barite are about a = 8.884 Å, b = 5.457 Å, c = 7.153 Å (giving a unit-cell volume ≈ 346.8 Å^3). The material is a wide-gap insulator with optical band gap in the ultraviolet; typical reported optical/experimental gaps are ~5–6 eV, so a representative prediction is 5.5 eV. The formation enthalpy of BaSO4 is strongly exothermic (literature ΔHf° ≈ −1.45 × 10^3 kJ/mol ≈ −15.24 eV per formula unit); dividing by 6 atoms per formula unit gives ≈ −2.54 eV/atom. Values given above assume the standard barite structure and experimental thermochemical data; DFT values may differ somewhat depending on functional and reference states.

BaSO4 (barite) is an insulating ionic sulfate that crystallizes in the orthorhombic barite structure (space group Pnma, Z = 4). Reported experimental optical band gaps are large (typically ≈5.5–6.0 eV); standard DFT (GGA) underestimates gaps, while experiment or hybrid calculations give values near 5.6–5.8 eV. I therefore predict a band gap of ~5.7 eV. For the formation energy I used typical tabulated standard enthalpies of formation for BaSO4 (≈ -1.44×10^3 kJ/mol) converted to eV per formula unit (≈ -14.9 eV/f.u.) and then divided by 6 atoms per formula unit (Ba + S + 4 O) to give ≈ -2.48 eV/atom. Lattice parameters are the well-known experimental room-temperature barite values (a ≈ 8.884 Å, b ≈ 5.458 Å, c ≈ 7.153 Å) giving a unit-cell volume ≈ 346.9 Å^3 (Z = 4). Uncertainties: band gap may vary by ~±0.3 eV depending on measurement/method; formation energy depends on the chosen reference data and whether enthalpy or internal energy is used and is therefore approximate to within a few tenths of an eV per atom.

BaSO4 crystallizes in the orthorhombic barite structure (space group Pnma). Reported experimental lattice constants for the conventional cell are about a = 8.884 Å, b = 5.457 Å, c = 7.156 Å (Z = 4), giving a unit-cell volume ≈ 346.8 Å^3. BaSO4 is a wide-gap insulator; experimental/optical band gaps are reported in the ~5.0–5.8 eV range. Density-functional calculations with semilocal functionals typically underestimate the gap, so an expected realistic band gap is ≈ 5.3 eV. For formation energy: using the standard enthalpy of formation of BaSO4 (≈ -1.41×10^3 kJ/mol as a representative literature value) gives ≈ -14.6 eV per formula unit; dividing by 6 atoms per formula unit yields ≈ -2.44 eV/atom. Values given above are for the conventional orthorhombic cell and an estimated/experimental reference gap and enthalpy; DFT-computed numbers may differ depending on functional and reference states used.

BaSO4 is the mineral barite (orthorhombic, commonly reported space group Pnma, 4 formula units per cell). Reported room-temperature lattice constants from crystallographic studies are about a = 8.884 Å, b = 5.457 Å, c = 7.153 Å, giving a unit-cell volume ≈ 346.8 Å^3. BaSO4 is a wide-gap ionic insulator; optical absorption/UV measurements and basic electronic-structure calculations place the fundamental/optical gap in the ~5–6 eV range, so a representative prediction is 5.6 eV. The standard enthalpy of formation for BaSO4 is ≈ −1348.5 kJ/mol (≈ −13.98 eV per formula unit). Dividing by 6 atoms per formula unit gives ≈ −2.33 eV/atom. These values are approximate (depend on measurement temperature and calculation method).

BaSO4 adopts the barite structure (orthorhombic Pnma, Z=4). Reported experimental lattice parameters for barite are approximately a = 8.88 Å, b = 5.46 Å, c = 7.15 Å (conventional cell), giving a unit-cell volume ≈ 3.47×10^2 Å^3. BaSO4 is a wide‑gap ionic insulator; optical gaps reported for alkaline-earth sulfates are in the several‑eV range. Taking typical experimental optical data and common DFT underestimation into account, a reasonable predicted band gap is ~5.8 eV. The standard enthalpy of formation of BaSO4 is large and negative (on the order of 1.4–1.6×10^3 kJ/mol); converting to eV per formula unit and then to per‑atom basis (6 atoms per formula unit: Ba+S+4O) gives about −2.5 eV/atom. Uncertainties: lattice constants reproducible to within a few 0.01–0.1 Å, band gap uncertain by ~±0.5 eV (method dependent), formation energy uncertain by a few 0.1 eV/atom depending on reference states and calculation method.
